entry.title: Quiz 7: Machine Learning
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of Machine Learning and clustering techniques. Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time. Push all your answers to quiz/7/ folder in your GitHub project.


  1. What is Machine Learning?
  2. Which one is a subset of another? Machine Learning, Deep Learning.
  3. What are the two broad categories of Machine Learning algorithms?
  4. Suppose we have fit the following red-line to the following blue dataset representing the global temperature increase of Earth over the past centuries.

    What kind of learning is this fit? supervised or unsupervised?
  5. What is the Kmeans algorithm in Machine Learning? Do we need to know the number of clusters a priori in the Kmeans method?
  6. What is the difference between the Kmeans and the Kmedioids algorithms?
  7. What is the difference between the Kmeans and the fuzzy C-Means algorithms?
  8. What is cluster analysis in Machine Learning?
  9. Name the four types of clustering methods.
  10. What is the difference between top-down and bottom-up Hierarchical clustering techniques?
  11. Does the DBSCAN clustering technique require the number of clusters to be known a priori? What (other) parameters have to be set before performing a DBSCAN clustering?
  12. Visit this website and choose the option Gaussian Mixture on the page to perform a DBSCAN on the Gaussian Mixture dataset. Adjust the two parameters of the DBSCAN algorithm such that there is no outlier (noise) point left after the clustering is done and all points become memebrs of some cluster. Take a screen-shot of the resulting clusters and submit the picture along with your responses.

Quiz 7: Machine Learning was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2021 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on December 03, 2021.

entry.title: Quiz 5: Logic and probability theory
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of Boolean Logic and Probability Theory. Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time. Push all your answers to quiz/5/ folder in your GitHub project.


  1. Please go to this survey and fill it out. It is completely anonymous and helps me (the instructor) to better serve your needs in this class. If you are worried about the quiz time, you can fill it out at the end of the quiz. link to the survey

  2. Name the four major definitions of Probability (corresponding to the four major schools of thought in probability theory).

  3. Which school(s) of probability theory define(s) probability as degree of confidence?

  4. Which school(s) of probability theory allow incorporation of expert (prior) knowledge in scientific inference?

  5. When data is scarce, which school of probability theory is the most useful for scientific inference?

  6. Name a prominent figure in each of the Frequentist and Bayesian schools of thought.

  7. What is epistemic uncertainty?

  8. What is aleatoric uncertainty?

  9. Suppose I have perfect vision. I throw a die multiple times and record the observed numbers. Obviously, every time it will be a different number. What is the type of uncertainty (source of variability) in the recorded observations?

  10. Which school of thought in Probability Theory cannot define or discuss the probability of existence of God? Why?

  11. NAND equivalence.

  12. If you have not filled out the survey, please do so. It is important. It is completely anonymous and helps me (the instructor) to better serve your needs in this class. link to the survey

Quiz 5: Logic and probability theory was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2021 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on November 05, 2021.

entry.title: Quiz 4: Inference and Logic
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of Scientific Inference and Logic. Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time. Push all your answers to quiz/4/ folder in your Github project.


  1. Name and describe briefly the steps involved in a scientific inference.

  2. What is the relationship between data and reality? Can we observe reality?

  3. What is the difference between model validation and calibration?

  4. Name the three pillars of science.

  5. Describe three different major applications of the third pillar of science with respect to the first two.

  6. Name the two different categories of logical reasoning and provide and example of each class.

  7. Is logical implication the same as physical causation? Explain with an example.

  8. Who is the Boolean algebra named after?

  9. Represent the logical conjunction via a Venn Diagram.

  10. Represent the logical disjunction via a Venn Diagram.

  11. What does it mean if two propositions have the same truth value?

  12. Display the logical implication $A \Rightarrow B$ via a Venn diagram.

  13. Explain, via Venn diagrams, that the logical equation $A = AB$ is equivalent to the logical implication $A \Rightarrow B$.

Quiz 4: Inference and Logic was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2021 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on October 21, 2021.

entry.title: Quiz 3: Data Visualization
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of Data Visualization. Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time. Push all your answers to quiz/3/ folder in your Github project.


  1. what are aesthetics in data visualization? Name a few aesthetics that can appear in a data visualization.

  2. Name the two major classes of aesthetics.

  3. What is the difference between factors and levels?

  4. Name the two major types of data and provide an example for each category.

  5. What is the common name for variables holding data?

  6. Provide examples of ordered and unordered data.

  7. What kinds of axes in a plot should be represented with the same units and grid size?

  8. Describe an example scenario where transforming the axes of the plot results in better visualizations.

  9. What kind of data set can be best visualized in polar coordinates?

  10. Name four different color scales and explain their most appropriate usage.

  11. Best visualization coloring.

  12. US cities temperatures.

  13. Colorscale classes.

  14. US states population growth.

  15. An ugly visualization.

  16. A wrong visualization.

  17. An Excel Bar plot.

  18. How would you distinguish exponential behavior vs. power-law behavior (function) in a 2-dimensional plot like this one?

  19. This graph displays the global land temperature anomaly of earth over the past 300 years. The vertical axis basically tells use how hot Earth has been in a given year compared to the average temperature during 1951-1980? Just by looking a this graph, do you think if the temperature of Earth will increase or decrease in the following decades? Approximately, how much hotter or cooler do you think Earth will be in 2050 with respect to the average temperature during 1951-1980 (the zero anomaly temperature)? Express your answer in units of Celsius.

Quiz 3: Data Visualization was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2021 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on October 08, 2021.

entry.title: Quiz 2: Programming History
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of programming history. Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time. Push all your answers to quiz/2/ folder in your Github project.


  1. What is the name of the fastest part of a computer memory?

    Answer: Register

  2. What is the slowest kind of computer storage device?

    Answer: External or Hard drive.

  3. Name the hierarchy of the memory of modern computers, from the smallest to the largest memory size?

    Answer: Register, L1, L2, L3, RAM, External or Hard drive.

  4. Which memory device is longer lasting: magnetic tapes or HDD hard-drives?

    Answer: Register, L1, L2, L3, RAM, External or Hard drive.

  5. What is smallest unit of information in computers?

    Answer: Register, L1, L2, L3, RAM, External or Hard drive.

  6. Why humans have chosen the binary numbers (0 and 1) to represent data in computers?

    Answer: Because binary information is readily representable by electric currents.

  7. What is the typical speed of contemporary computer registers?

    Answer: On the order of nanoseconds.

  8. What decade was the first digital computer built?

    Answer: 1940’

  9. What is a fixed program computer?

    Answer: Early models of computers that could only perform certain tasks.

  10. What is the difference between declarative and imperative knowledge?

    Answer: Declarative knowledge involves statements of fact. Imperative knowledge is about how to accomplish something, or basically, is a recipe on how to do something, known as algorithm in scientific terminology.

  11. What class of human knowledge algorithms belong to?

    Answer: Imperative knowledge.

  12. What is a computer bug?

    Answer: An error in program that has to be resolved for successful execution of the program.

  13. What is a compiler?

    Answer: A software that translates an entire high-level program into a lower-level language to make it executable.

  14. What is the name of the first digital computer?

    Answer: ENIAC.

  15. Name a computer programming language whose evolution and popularity is tightly coupled with the field of Bioinformatics.

    Answer: Python.

  16. Name a computer programming language whose evolution and popularity is tightly coupled with the field of Numerical Computing, Atmospheric Science, Plasma Sciences, and Aerospace Engineering, among others.

    Answer: Fortran.

  17. Name the five major components of a modern digital computer.

    Answer: input device, CPU, main memory, external storage, output device.

  18. Name an example of fixed-program computer.

    Answer: Calculators.

  19. Order the following languages chronologically according to their birth date.

    Java, COBOL, C++, Python, Fortran, Julia, B Answer: Fortran, COBOL, B, C++, Java, Python, Julia

  20. (A) What is the closest programming language to machine code (i.e., binary code)?

    Answer: Assembly

    (B) Does it need interpretation in order to become machine-comprehensible?

    Answer: Yes. An Assembler interprets the program for the machine.

  21. (A) Name the oldest high-level programming language that is still in active daily use.

    Answer: Fortran

    (B) Approximately how many decades is it old? ($\pm15$ years is acceptable answer. the decade it was created is also an acceptable answer)

    Answer: in 1950s

  22. (A) Name a second-generation programming language.

    Answer: Assembly

    (B) Which language-generation are Fortran, C, C++, MATLAB, Python, R?

    Answer: third, third, third, fourth, fourth, fourth

  23. In what decades C, C++, and MATLAB/Python were created, respectively?

    Answer: 1970s, 1980s, 1980s, 1990s

  24. Name an ancestor programming language of C.

    Answer: B

  25. Name a programming language ancestor of C++.

    Answer: C, Simula

  26. Name a programming language ancestor of MATLAB and a programming language ancestor of Python.

    Answer: Fortran/C

  27. How do you define logarithm? Explain with an example.

    Answer: The logarithm in bae of 10, the exponent that if the number 10 is raised to, then it yields the original number. For example, log10(100) = 2.

Quiz 2: Programming History was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2021 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on September 27, 2021.

entry.title: Homework 2: Programming History
entry.content:
♣ Due Date: Friday September 24, 2021 9:00 AM. This homework aims at giving you some experience with computer hardware and software. Please write your answers in a README.md file and push them all to HW/2/ folder of your repository on GitHub.

  1. What does ENIAC stand for?

  2. Why is everything represented by integers in computers?

  3. What is the name of the fastest part of the computer memory?

  4. What is the slowest storage device in computers (that is typically integrated with computers)?

  5. What is the smallest unit of information in computer science?

  6. (A) What is the closest programming language to machine code (i.e., binary code)?

    (B) Does it need interpretation in order to become machine-comprehensible?

  7. (A) Name the oldest high-level programming language that is still in active daily use.

    (B) Approximately how many decades is it old? ($\pm15$ years is acceptable answer. the decade it was created is also an acceptable answer)

  8. (A) Name a second-generation programming language.

    (B) Which language-generation are Fortran, C, C++, MATLAB, Python, R?

  9. In what decades C, C++, and MATLAB/Python were created, respectively?

  10. Name an ancestor programming language of C.

  11. Name a programming language ancestor of C++.

  12. Name a programming language ancestor of MATLAB and a programming language ancestor of Python.

  13. What are the three common types of errors in computer programs? Provide an example for each category.

  14. Suppose you write a program that has memory leak. What type of programming error you dealing with?

  15. Extra credit: What are the three fundamental components of a Turing-complete language?

  16. Extra credit: How would you distinguish exponential behavior vs. power-law behavior (function) in a 2-dimensional plot?
    Hint: Recall our discussion of the ENAIC project and the relative frequency of keywords such as “computer” in our programming.

Homework 2: Programming History was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2021 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on September 20, 2021.

entry.title: Quiz 1: Intro. Data Science, Version Control Systems
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of Version Control System and some topics discussed in the history of Data Science. Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time. Push all your answers to quiz/1/ folder in your Github project.


  1. Write down the Git command that lists all Git commands for you.

    Answer:

    $ git help -a

  2. Name four newly emerging branches of science that are growing exponentially fast with respect to the traditional fields of science.

    Answer:
    Neuroscience, Biomedical Science, Bioinformatics, Computational Physics, Data Science

  3. Name and briefly describe the three different areas in a Git project.

    Answer:
    XXX

  4. What is a Version Control System (VCS)? A brief explanation is enough.

    Answer:
    XXX

  5. Name four modern scientific tools or algorithms that have been growing exponentially fast in popularity over the past decades.

    Answer:
    Artificial Intelligence, MCMC, Machine Learning, Computers

  6. Name 6 major benefits of using distributed VCS as opposed to not using any VCS at all for project indexing and maintenance.

    Answer:
    See this page

  7. Name the three major historical classes of VCS.

    Answer:
    See this page

  8. What is Git and how is it different from GitHub?

    Answer:
    See this page

  9. What is SSH?

    Answer:
    See this page

  10. What does git status command do?

    Answer:
    See this page

  11. What does git push --all command do?

    Answer:
    See this page

  12. What does git pull command do?

    Answer:
    See this page

  13. What does git log command do?

    Answer:
    See this page

  14. Which of the following Git commands can add all the new and modified-existing files to the staging area? choose all that apply.

    (A) git add -A
    (B) git add --A
    (C) git add -all
    (D) git add --all
    (E) git add -u
    (F) git add .
    (G) git add .; git add -u
    (H) git add .; git add --u
    (I) git add -u; git add .
    (J) git add --u; git add .

    Answer: A, D, G, F, I

  15. Which of the following Git commands both stages and commits only modified and deleted files but NOT the new files added to the repository since the last commit. Choose all that apply.

    (A) git commit
    (B) git commit -a
    (C) git commit -am

    Answer: B, C

Quiz 1: Intro. Data Science, Version Control Systems was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2021 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on September 13, 2021.

entry.title: Homework 1: Version Control Using Git and Github
entry.content:
♣ Due Date: Friday September 10, 2021 9:00 AM. This homework aims at giving you some experience on how to work with Git and GitHub.

  1. Version-control using Git and GitHub ONLY part 1.
  2. Name the three historical types of Version Control Systems.
  3. Which one of the three historical types of Version Control Systems is best and why is it the best?
  4. Briefly describe what the following git commands do.
    a. git pull
    b. git status
    c. git add --all
    d. git commit -m"latest build"
    e. git push --all
  5. In your repository for this course on GitHub (named IDS2021F, standing for Introduction to Data Science 2021 Fall), create the following folders,
    a. hw
    b. quiz
    c. exam
    Inside the hw folder, create another folder named 1. Inside this folder create a README.md file containing your answers to the above questions.
    Hint: You can either do the above tasks inside the local clone of your repository and push it to the remote copy of the repository on GitHub or, you can create all of the folders and subfolders and files on the GitHub page of your project.

Homework 1: Version Control Using Git and Github was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2021 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on September 01, 2021.
